tutorials.title: Introduction to FFStudio
tutorials.description: See how FFStudio brings the full power of FFmpeg into a visual graph system for media engineers and developers.
tutorials.intro: FFmpeg is the foundation of modern media processing. It powers transcoding farms, streaming services, broadcast automation, and countless editing pipelines. But building and maintaining large, reliable FFmpeg workflows often means juggling complex commands, testing variations, and dealing with long scripts. FFStudio was created to change that — a graph-based interface that exposes *all* of FFmpeg, while giving engineers clarity, flexibility, and speed.

sections.title: The Challenge of CLI Workflows
sections.content:
Here’s a typical command you might use in FFmpeg:

```bash ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -i logo.png -filter_complex "[0:v]scale=1280:720[v0]; [v0][1:v]overlay=10:10:enable='between(t,0,20)'[vout]" -map "[vout]" -map 0:a:0 -c:v libx264 -b:v 2500k -c:a aac -b:a 128k output.mp4```

This one command scales a video to 720p, overlays a logo for the first 20 seconds, keeps the first audio track, and encodes with H.264 + AAC. It’s powerful — but it’s also hard to read, debug, or extend when your pipeline grows to multiple filters, mappings, or outputs.

sections.title: The FFStudio Approach
sections.content:
In FFStudio, the same operation is built visually:
- **Input Node** → your video file.
- **Filter Nodes** → scale, then overlay.
- **Encoder Nodes** → H.264 for video, AAC for audio.
- **Output Node** → final MP4.

Instead of parsing a long string, you *see* the workflow as a connected graph. Each node is configured with the same options FFmpeg exposes, but the structure is clear, reusable, and easy to extend.

sections.title: Parsing FFmpeg Into Nodes
sections.content:
FFStudio doesn’t just wrap a single FFmpeg binary. It understands *your* FFmpeg build. By running commands like `ffmpeg -h full` or `ffmpeg -h encoder=libx264`, FFStudio parses the documentation directly from FFmpeg’s self-describing preprocessor system. That means:

- Every codec, filter, muxer, and option in your FFmpeg build is discoverable.
- Node inputs, outputs, and parameters are generated automatically.
- Custom FFmpeg builds with proprietary or experimental modules become first-class citizens in the UI.

This way, FFStudio stays in sync with FFmpeg — no feature hidden, no lock-in.

sections.title: Bring Your Own FFmpeg
sections.content: You’re not limited to the version of FFmpeg bundled with the app. In FFStudio, you specify the path to the binary and its environment variables (like shared libraries). FFStudio then parses that binary and exposes all of its capabilities. For developers working with patched builds, new filters, or hardware acceleration modules, this means total freedom. Your custom FFmpeg becomes fully usable in a visual environment — no compromises.

sections.title: Who Benefits?
sections.content:
FFStudio is designed for:
- **Media engineers** building and maintaining transcoding farms.
- **Developers** integrating FFmpeg into larger processing pipelines.
- **Researchers & enthusiasts** experimenting with new codecs or custom filters.

Instead of wrestling with giant command strings, you design, save, and share workflows as visual graphs — reproducible and maintainable. FFStudio is not a toy GUI; it’s a productivity layer for raw FFmpeg.

tutorials.conclusion: FFStudio combines the raw power of FFmpeg with the clarity of a graph-based workflow. By exposing every feature of your chosen FFmpeg build, it removes the guesswork and speeds up development. In the next tutorial, we’ll get hands-on: exploring the interface and creating your first workflow.

tutorials.title: Video Compression Techniques
tutorials.description: Optimize your video files without sacrificing quality using FFStudio's compression nodes.
tutorials.intro: Video compression is essential for efficient storage and streaming. This tutorial will teach you how to achieve the perfect balance between file size and video quality using FFStudio's advanced compression tools.

sections.title: Understanding Video Compression
sections.content: Learn the fundamentals of video compression, including codecs, bitrates, and quality settings. Understanding these concepts will help you make informed decisions about your compression workflow.

sections.title: Setting Up Compression Nodes
sections.content: Configure FFStudio's compression nodes for optimal results. We'll explore different compression algorithms and their specific use cases.

sections.title: Quality vs. File Size Optimization
sections.content: Master the art of balancing quality and file size. Learn techniques to maintain visual quality while achieving significant file size reductions.

tutorials.conclusion: You now have the knowledge and tools to create efficient, high-quality video compression workflows. Apply these techniques to optimize your video projects for various platforms and requirements.
